accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Special formats separated from the body of the collection are stored in the following containers:
Audiovisual holdings (primarily FA772:161- ) are temporarily assigned to Box 150.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Record Group 1 of the National Committee on United States – China Relations records (FA772) contains records of the National Committee's events and exchanges programs, primarily for the period 1982 to 2014; conference records; and National Committee publications and reports.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Committee on United States – China Relations (NCUSCR) was established in 1966 as a nonprofit educational organization with a mission to encourage mutual understanding and dialogue between citizens of the United States and China.

The National Committee came into being through the cooperative efforts of scholars and civic, religious, and business leaders who, at a time of mutual hostility between the two countries, sought to stimulate public discussion about China and the United States' relations with it by sponsoring conferences, seminars, publications, and other education and outreach programs. In 1972, the National Committee sponsored the Chinese table tennis team's historic U. S. visit. This round of "Ping Pong Diplomacy," which followed closely on Richard Nixon's visit to China in February 1972, helped pave the way for later exchanges and, eventually, for the normalization of relations with China in 1979. Building on these cultural exchanges, the National Committee came to be a primary organizer of professional and policy exchanges between the two countries (and including Hong Kong and Taiwan), in the areas of foreign affairs and international relations, economic development, governance and legal affairs, education, mass media, environmental and global issues, etc. As its role in exchanges became more prominent, the National Committee turned over some of its educational programs to the Asia Society in the late 1970s, but it continues its educational role through public education events and ongoing outreach.
Funding for the National Committee comes from the United States government (especially the Department of State), corporations, and foundations, as well as from its individual membership.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the National Committee on United States – China Relations are divided into ten record groups, which reflect the order in which the records were received (but which are otherwise an artificial distinction). The records are sorted intellectually into series, which carry over through all record groups, but they have received little or no physical rearrangement.

RG 1 of the NCUSCR records is arranged into six series: 1 - Events; 2 - Exchanges - General; 3 - Exchanges to China; 4 - Exchanges from China; 5 - Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues; and 6 - Publications and Reports.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The National Committee on United States-China Relations donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated March 27, 2015.

did.unittitle: Events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Events series (Series 1) includes annual members programs; luncheons and dinner meetings, often honoring visiting dignitaries, or featuring foreign policy leaders or speakers from academia, government, or business; corporate or member briefings on topical issues; and biennial gala dinners and special anniversary programs. Most events were held in New York or Washington, DC, but the series includes some briefings held in Beijing, Shanghai, or Hong Kong.
The Events files can be uneven in contents. They often include considerable detail on arrangements and planning, but sometimes contain very little on the subject matter.
Events, Exchanges, and Conference files are dated according to the event or trip dates. These dates do not necessarily reflect the precise date range of the contents.

Fortieth Anniversary Book (American Participants)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Forty at Forty." On the occasion of its fortieth anniversary, the NCUSCR solicited comments and reflections from twenty American and twenty Chinese participants in its programs. While the files are nominally divided into American and Chinese responses, the responses are intermixed between the files. A set of forty responses is found at the front of this folder, but there is no finished booklet in the file.

Exchanges - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records relating to Exchange programs are arranged in three series: Exchanges - General (Series 2), Exchanges to China (Series 3), and Exchanges from China (Series 4). Exchange delegations focused on topics of international relations, public policy, government and judicial administration, educational policy and administration, media, economic development, the environment, NGOs and the non-profit sector, among other issues, and were composed of state or local officials (particularly for the Chinese delegates), professionals, academics, or administrators. Some exchanges were paired programs, where a delegation from one country received a visit in turn from the other country the following year.

The Exchanges - General series (Series 2) contains records documenting some of the more formal — and reciprocal — exchange programs, in particular the U. S. – China Teachers Exchange Program (TEP), from its inception in 1996 up to 2014. The files include the TEP's newsletter publication, The Exchange, 1996 – 2003. Materials in RG 1 particularly document the Chinese exchange teachers, including a full run of files on the individual teachers, and orientation materials from approximately 2001–2009. The Chinese teachers' files for the earlier years in particular (up to 2000 or so) contain correspondence that can be quite rich in detail on teaching, travel, difficulties, and follow-up adjustments. Files for later participants tend to be more routine and may contain little of interest beyond the application and assignment letter. This series also includes orientation materials for U.S. teachers going to China from 1996–2004 and 2007–2012, and a set of briefing books for participants in the Fulbright-Hays Seminars Abroad in China, for 2005–2007 and 2010. RG 1 does not encompass the records of individual U. S. teachers in the TEP or Fulbright program.
Events, Exchanges, and Conference files are dated according to the event or trip dates. These dates do not necessarily reflect the precise date range of the contents.

did.unittitle: The Exchange, Volume 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newsletter for the Participants in and Friends of the U.S. - China Teachers Exchange Program. Sponsored by the American Council of Learned Societies, New York, and the Chinese Education Association for International Exchange, Beijing. In June 2002, administration and sponsorship of the Teachers Exchange Program moved from the American Council of Learned Societies to the National Committee. Volume 1, Numbers 1-3. Two copies of each issue.

did.unittitle: Exchanges to China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records relating to Exchange programs are arranged in three series: Exchanges - General (Series 2), Exchanges to China (Series 3), and Exchanges from China (Series 4). Exchange delegations focused on topics of international relations, public policy, government and judicial administration, educational policy and administration, media, economic development, the environment, NGOs and the non-profit sector, among other issues, and were composed of state or local officials (particularly for the Chinese delegates), professionals, academics, or administrators. Some exchanges were paired programs, where a delegation from one country received a visit in turn from the other country the following year.
Events, Exchanges, and Conference files are dated according to the event or trip dates. These dates do not necessarily reflect the precise date range of the contents.

Exchanges from China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records relating to Exchange programs are arranged in three series: Exchanges - General (Series 2), Exchanges to China (Series 3), and Exchanges from China (Series 4). Exchange delegations focused on topics of international relations, public policy, government and judicial administration, educational policy and administration, media, economic development, the environment, NGOs and the non-profit sector, among other issues, and were composed of state or local officials (particularly for the Chinese delegates), professionals, academics, or administrators. Some exchanges were paired programs, where a delegation from one country received a visit in turn from the other country the following year.
Events, Exchanges, and Conference files are dated according to the event or trip dates. These dates do not necessarily reflect the precise date range of the contents.

Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues series (Series 5) notably contains the records of the U. S. Foreign Policy Colloquium, 2002–2011, an educational program in Washington, DC, which the National Committee organized for Chinese students studying or working in the U. S. The series also includes various conference records for the period 1988–1994.
Events, Exchanges, and Conference files are dated according to the event or trip dates. These dates do not necessarily reflect the precise date range of the contents.
